comments.commentBody: An atheist with agnostic leanings? That's a contradiction. Analogous to saying, "There is no magic ... unless there is."

If I wasn't an atheist with agnostic leanings I would definitely support this cause. On a larger scale (a few thousand divided by 1.6 billion), I think it is important to note that the Iranian/Shia affiliations have not imported the same degree of reactionary fundamentalism from that Emirate which Shall Not Be Named. I don't know how these guns end up doing so much damage. Apparently, the second amendment did not have the future of civilization in mind, nor the blood thirsty Guided Assault Rifle Party that has no issue with politicizing tragedy and thereby setting off a chain reaction.

I loved the clever use of roman numerals in word form! The III got me started, having grown up in a family that watched Walter Cronkite every night on the CBSeveningnews.  The shaded squares were a big help.  Thanks for a very fun puzzle!

Thank goodness Republicans in the Senate spent the day on legislation to defund Planned Parenthood and Obamacare (again.) Of course neither is going anywhere, but otherwise, they might have had time to discuss stuff like outlawing assault rifles.

A modern combine harvester can do the job of 200 people.

What would happen to the price of a loaf of bread if combine harvesters were outlawed and farmers were required to pay workers $15 an hour plus benefits to harvest grain with hand-held scythes? Would the overall impact on the standard of living be positive or negative? For the answer, just look at any third world country where everything is done by hand.

As an economics grad, the cynic in me agrees.  As a former Wall Streeter who's seen thousands of jobs disappear to automation [final proof: the venerable NY Stock Exchange gobbled up by a 10 year old black box firm] one sees the irony in capitalism.  Now, as a transition coach, I see daily evidence that the buck stops at the individual for their complacency, even among the highly credentialed.  There's no faster way to be put out to pasture than to coast.

The assertion that automation -- historically and presently -- does not kill jobs is endlessly repeated.  Yet theres no empirical evidence that supports and plenty of empirical evidence to falsify it.  Economists make the assertion for two reasons:  to assure that all is well in the free market for labor, and, perhaps more important for the economists, to bolster the collapsing micro economics taught in our universities.  Shame on them.

Sam Peters : Your interpretation is completely wrong. If you go through this comment and the other comments clearly, you will understand that spending too much in the name of security, technology and defence simply doesn't help.

The mega investment by any country is very much required in the fields of education, healthcare, providing employment opportunities in various industries, government, new infrastructure and also for revamping the crumbled existing infrastructure.

Big investment is very much required in the renewable source of energy and also efforts should be made for improving the quality of coal. Further all out efforts should be made in making education especially higher education affordable so that students need not suffer from the huge college debt.

It would be more helpful to the youth if college education is made in synchronisation with the industries so that employment problem gets reduced to a larger extent. Further practical courses in plumbing, carpentry, electrician, Airconditioner and Refrigerator repairs, TV and other electronic goods repair etc should be started and encouraged.

All of the above mentioned steps will surely help any country to progress and definitely not very very very very high expenditure in defence.

I think the time is ripe to repeal the 2nd Amendment. I did not say prohibit gun ownership, just remove the Constitutional right. Let states regulate ownership, under a Federal requirement to register and insure. Of course there will be illegal guns, as there has been and always will be criminal behavior. But being a criminal usually requires extra effort. Let's remove the easiness of violence.
Write to your representatives, let's get this started!

For the umpteenth time, Islamists are not the problem much as Christians would like to just respect their faith in private.
Its the kids with guns and bombs to easily available using religion as an excuse to harm others.
Families of any religion can only do so much.
The babies, essentially, are the hope.
The assailants left their six month old with their grandmother while going on their killing spree. During the killing they murdered a Father of six, one of which is around the same age as they left with their grandmother.
Both families are going to pick up the Flag as it were to make sure the kids grow up.
But they are going to grow up and possibly face each other in the future.
Both will have a right to throw a knife into each other.
But will they?

Jim, I very much doubt that you are a lifelong liberal, but whatever. I have never read a comment decrying gun violence that blames "all gun owners" or lays the blame for a shooting such as that at Planned Parenthood at the "collective" feet of ChristIans.

One problem it seems to me is that in our majority white country, where mass murders occur all too frequently, most often committed by young white men, minorities as a whole are held up for more scrutiny when a member of their community commits such an act. We whites aren't expected to apologize and prove our worth as citizens every time a white guy or gal goes postal.

This happened just yesterday, some things point to ISIL type radicalization with the workplace angle adding confusion. We have competent law enforcement agencies on the case, all will be revealed. The worst outcome though is placing guilt and judgements on all Americans who happen to be Muslim and we have candidates for president playing that dangerous game.
It's a combo deal.  Guns & religious certainty.

Are there background checks for religious affiliation, theology and church membership? If a religion is "peaceful" -- as most religions claim to be -- do they screen their members for gun ownership, mental health, and an inclination to slaughter non-believers?

Both recent massacres appear to be motivated by religious beliefs. Excluding shooters who hear voices from Neptune, do we have a gun problem or a God problem?

In the midst of this horror, I found it cunning that it was suggested that we wait until facts develop to decide whether or not the San Bernandino massacre involved terrorism. I do not understand, as the administration has not heretofore hesitated to announce its opinions in the absence of any need to do so and at risk of interfering with individuals' reputations and rights, including fair trial rights. Yet when violence broke out at Fort Hood, the nation's love of due process was extolled. Both awaiting facts and according due process are of the utmost importance, which means that they are not of the utmost importance only for some.

This evening I attended a presentation in which there was discussion of fear of immigrants as spies or subversive during World War II. This was much pooh-poohed as silly. Yet there is some evidence that embedding can occur, and surely the enormity of the mass migrations in Europe would lend themselves to such measures. Being circumspect about resettlement seems reasonable and should not be derided as an opposition to widows and orphans.

How did we get here? Multiple causes, no doubt. But likewise it is of no doubt that we have fallen farther faster than anyone might have imagined. Rampant violence from within and without. Painful to the bone for all of us.

President Obama's illegal drone campaign is absolutely terrorism.  The failure of his  team to accurately understand how deadly the "JV Team" could be and to ignore their progression as they increased in both size and capability and to effectively address the issue is the reason we are where we are today.  His mismanagement of the debacle Bush started has only exacerbated the problem.

Self radicalization is not an easily prevented disease.  It occurs in the isolation of a home and in the brain of an individual.  It occurs in the dead of the night and in the light of the day but it occurs in the shadows and behind the scenes.  It occurs quietly in cyberspace.  It occurs patiently.  It is prepared to wait.  It is determined and silent.  It is like a volcano that is dormant until it blows its top off.  To boot, jihadists use Western technology and various Western freedoms to strike at the heart of Western democracies.  This attack was symbolic.  It happened at a Christmas party--a venue ripe for martyrdom and war against the infidels.  The West is completely unprepared for this asymmetrical warfare with Islam's radicals.  The West is impatient, boastful, open, defiant and most importantly free.  It is a sitting duck for the radicals.  But all hate runs its course.  The West invited this radicalism with its Middle East wars.  The genii of terror is out of the box in full force and the radicals in Ali Baba's cave say, "Open Sesame!" as and when they please.  We cannot kill our way out of terrorism. We cannot talk our way out.  We must live and die as the Israelis and the Palestinians have, as have so many others in the Middle East and across Asia, until the furor dies a natural death.

One of the many detriments of the "politically correct" policies of non assimilation is that is forces people who come to this country to not integrate into American culture.  This creates silos of isolation that often exacerbate the alienation that radical thinking preys upon to find its pawns

It is not stockpiling. Any serious responsible fiirearm owner has a personal responsibility to maintain shooting skills. Especially those with CCW permits and hunters.

If you hone your skills at proper range facilities you go through 50 to 100 rounds each time. Range shooting on a regular basis, say 1 a week, and 1,000 rounds last between 110 to 15 weeks.

Ground shipping costs are based on number of packages and total weight so buying 2 cases of 1,000 rounds of 9 mm or .223 ammunition which are packed in one shipping box will save about $10 per order v.s. two single 1,000 round orders. There is also usually a 10% lower price per round due to the quantity ordered vs single 50 round boxes.

The motive is so far from irrelevant it is hard to overstate it.

It isn't because they profess a belief in Islam that this will be considered worse than others. .. It is because he did things like communicating with known radical jihadis, building multiple explosive devices, and obviously put a great deal of planning into this. In other words extremist ideology played someBat least non-trivial and possibly extremely large role in motivating this, it is happening more often, and had been spreading around the world.

By the way - pipe bombs are already 100% completely illegal. We do need gun reform, their access to firearms is hardly what matters most.

It was a "Holiday Party", which are the P C code words for a Christmas party, and yes they are taking place this week. I have seen two the past two nights in the restaurant in the ground floor of the office building where I work. More to the point, even folks on the left coast and those that work in government have "Holiday Parties" along with sending "Season's Greetings" cards or cards that read "Happy Holidays".

Workplace violence? Yes, but so was the Fort Hood shooting if you want to look at it that way. Another example of what happens in a country where everyone can get ahold of a firearm? Well, France has strict gun control and that did not stop radical Islamists from shooting up Paris.

These terrorists would have found a way to kill no matter what the gun laws would have been. Fact is California has some the most strident gun control in the US and it did not stop a determined terrorist from creating mayhem.

To stop terrorism we need to stop American militarism on behalf of corporations. Leave regional problems to nations in the region and stop the influence of foreign money in our political system so that Americans can be told the truth about world events. Bush/Obama created this problem not the NRA and its time to stop the militaristic approach that will be furthered by Hillary or any other Republican elected President. If we want to stop terrorism we need to vote in a new an enlightened way.

"Amercan exceptionalism":  the last developed country to allow human slavery; the perpetrator of the largest genocide and ethnic cleansing in history.  Yup:  we certainly are exceptional (fortunately).

Absolutely right! China an oppressive Totalitarian government security of itself and dominance over its people by making sure they don't have weapons to resist. Nice example.

The Arab Spring was not brought about with candy canes

I have not heard of one comment where someone who knew this man had a cordial and close friendship with him. I heard the neighbor say she always said "hi" and even met his mother, but didn't know his name. A co-worker is reported to have had a run-in with him regarding a discussion about religion. His co-workers threw a baby shower for him. I would not read too much into that. In m experience, people sometimes like to have something happy to celebrate. It doesn't mean he was close to anybody there.
He didn't even have friendships among the fellow worshipers at the mosque he frequented.
No-one seems to have information about the wife, other than that she was born in Pakistan and lived in Saudi Arabia before coming here. I have even read some reports that her name might be ficticious.

This is incorrect.  Terrorism is violence committed in furtherance of political agenda.  Ex someone suffering a pychotic episdone that goes on a mass shooting at a shopping mall is not terrorism.  Neither would a mass shooting caused by a workplace dispute, for that matter.
But we make it so easy for them to get the guns.  The French at least try to prevent it.
It has to be politically motivated to qualify as terrorism.
I agree. I can only hope lawmakers do, too.
Either that or shoot one another so the rest of us can get on peaceably.
